name: allocating
content:

present participle of
allocate
C1 to give something to someone as their share of a total amount, to use in a particular way: The government is allocating £10 million for health education. [ + two objects ] As project leader, you will have to allocate people jobs/allocate jobs to people. It is not the job of the investigating committee to allocate blame for the disaster/to allocate blame to individuals. Synonym
apportion formal
More examplesFewer examplesThe local council has decided not to allocate funds for the project.The president has agreed to allocate further funds to develop the new submarine.Tickets will be allocated on a first-come, first-served basis.There are ten marks allocated to every question.Try to allocate yourself a set time each day to practise your exercises.
